PAGE: 1
HEADING: BRACCIFORTI

Braarud, Trygave (1903-1985), Norwegian marine botanist, studied with H.H. Gran at the
University of Oslo, cand. real 1927, Dr. phil. 1936, "amanensis" and lecturer in General
Botany 1936-1947, held the Chair of Marine Botany at Oslo 1947-1973, specialized in
biological oceanography and marine ecology, founder of the Norwegian Institute of Seaweed
Research (1950) and the Norwegian Institute of Water Research (1958), one of the "founding
fathers" of the International Phycological Society. (<em>Braarud</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: O (Algae).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: IH 2: 91; Roon p. 21.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Norw. J. Bot. 20(2-3): 75. 1973 (portr.).
Hasle, G.R., Nordic J. Bot. 6(1): 98. 1986 (obit., portr.).
Paasche, E., Blyttia 44: 50-52. 1986 (obit., portr.).
Prescott, G.W., Bibl. Desmid. univ. 68. 1984.
Vaage, J., Blyttia 43: 162, 164. 1985 (portr., founding Norw. Bot. Assoc.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Braarudosphaera</em> Deflandre (1947), see Blyttia 45: 103. 1987 and ING 1: 228.
1979.

22.486. A note on the <em>phytoplankton of the Gulf of Maine</em> in the summer of 1933 ... Reprinted
from Biological Bulletin ... 1934. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Aug 1934 (in journal), p. 76-82. <em>Copy</em>: L. - Reprinted and to be cited from Biol. Bull.
	67(1): 76-82. 1934.

22.487. The <em>Øst Expedition to the Denmark Strait</em> 1929. II. The <em>phytoplankton</em> and its
conditions of growth (including some qualitative data from the Arctic in 1930) ... Oslo (I
Kommisjon hos Jacob Dybwad) 1935. Oct. (<em>Exp. Denmark Strait, Phytoplankton</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Shortly after 9 Jul 1935 (date of printing on p. [174]), cover-t.p., p. [1]-173, [174].
	<em>Copy</em>: L. - Issued as no. 10 Hvalrådets Skrifter, Oslo, 1935.
<em>Note</em>: (1) The first part of this publication (by T. Braarud and J.T. Ruud) 1932 dealt with
	<em>Hydrography</em>.
	(2) A further publ. before 1940 dealt with <em>A quantitative study of the phytoplankton in the
	Bay of Fundy and the Gulf of Maine</em>, J. Biol. Canada 1: 5 seq. 1935.

22.488. <em>Microspores in Diatoms</em> ... Reprinted from Nature ... 1939. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 27 Mai 1939 (in journal; text dated 21 Apr 1939), p. [1]-2. <em>Copy</em>: L. - Reprinted and
	to be cited from Nature 143: 899. 1939.

Bracciforti, Alberto (Conte) (1838-?), Italian botanist at Piacenza. (<em>Braccif</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 236 (b. 22 Jan 1838, Piacenza); BL 2: 350 (<em>Fl.
piacent.</em> and further info.); Jackson p. 10, 320; Rehder 1: 74; Saccardo 1: 36-37; Tucker 1: 104.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Zeit. 45: 710. 28 Oct 1887 (mentions a <em>Flora di giardini publici e viali
	di Spezia</em>, Spezia 1887, 22 p., n.v.).

22.489. <em>Flora piacentina</em> ossia enumerazione sistematica delle piante della Provincia di
Piacenza coll'indicazione delle loro stazioni, dei caratteri principali di ciascuna familia, dei
nomi italiani, di quelli del dialetto piacento, con osservazioni e note etimologiche ... Piacenza
(Tipografia F. Solari) 1877. Oct. (<em>Fl. piacent.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1877, p. [1]-384. <em>Copy</em>: NY.
<em>Note</em>: Published also a "Dizionarietto botanico piacentino-latino", Piacenza 1877 n.v. (Rehder
	1: 74, Local names. Has an appendix: "Flora of Piacenza", n.v.).

PAGE: 2
HEADING: BRACHET

Brachet, Flavien (x-1910), French botanist in Rémollon (Hautes-Alpes), teacher and guide
on excursions at Gap in the Hautes-Alpes. (<em>Brachet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Mainly in G (labels: Flavien Brachet, Plantes du Département des
Hautes-Alpes), further material in DBN, MPU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 12(2): 250; Barnhart 1: 237 (d. Mai 1910, Rémollon,
Hts. Alp.); BL 2: 160; Tucker 1: 104.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 50(4) (Beibl.): (192). 1910 (d.).

22.490. <em>Excursions botaniques de Briançon</em> aux sources de la Durance et de la Clarée
(Hautes-Alpes). Petit guide du botaniste herborisant ... Gap (L. Jean &amp; Peyrot, ...) 1907. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Jul-Sep 1907 (in journal), cover-t.p., p. [1-4], uncol. map. [5]-51, [52, identif.]. <em>Copy</em>:
	G. - Reprinted and to be cited from Bull. Soc. d'Études, Hist. Sci. Litt. Hautes-Alpes, Gap
	23, 3° trimestre 1907 (n.v.).

*Brackenridge, William Dunlop (1810-1893), Scottish born horticulturist and botanist,
settled in America ca. 1837, joined the Wilkes U.S. Exploring Expedition 1838-1842, charged
with the living plants collected by the expedition, 1842-1854 at Washington D.C. (until 1852
horticulturist at the U.S. Bot. Garden), settled in Baltimore 1855 as floriculturist and garden
architect. (<em>Brack</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US (incl. drawings, proofs), some further material at PH (not from
Wilkes Exp.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 80; Barnhart 1: 237 (b. 10 Jun 1810, Ayr, Scotland,
d. 3 Feb 1893, Baltimore, Md.); BB p. 42; BM 1: 219; Bossert p. 49; DAB; Desmond p. 83
(further refs.); Ewan ed. 1: 19, 168, 283, 317, ed. 2: 24-25; Hortus 3: 1189; HR; IF p. 684;
Kew 1: 333-334; Lenley p. 448 (corr. Torrey); ME 1: 167, 3: 542 (index); PR 1073; Rehder
1: 509, 3: 116; SK 1: 74-75; TL-2/1: 299 and see indexes; Tucker 1: 104.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Alden, R.H. and J.D. Ifft, Occas. Pap. Calif. Acad. Sci. 20: 49, 53. 1943.
Anon., Amer. Florist 8: 678, 698. 1893 (portr.).
Barnhart, J.H., J. New York Bot. Gard. 20(234): 117-124. 1919 (B. and his book on ferns
	[TL-2/697]).
Bartlett, H.H., Proc. Amer. Philos. Soc. 82: 673-679. 1940 (coll.).
Brackenridge, W.D., Journal of W.D. Brackenridge, 1-28 Oct 1841 [in California], Calif.
	Hist. Soc. Quart. 24: 326-336. Dec 1845.
Brewer, W.H., <em>in</em> S. Watson, Bot. Calif. 2: 555. 1880.
Britten, J., J. Bot. 57: 263. 1919.
Carr, D.J. and S.G.M., eds., People and plants in Australia 252. 1981.
Coats, A.M., The plant hunters 295, 297-299, 309. 1969.
Ewan, J., <em>in</em> A century of progress in the natural sciences 45. 1955.
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 8, 9, 42, 97. 1969.
Eyde, R.H., Huntia 6(2): 165-196. 1986 (in a paper on William Rich).
Gager, C.S., Brooklyn Bot. Gard. Record 27(3): 358. 1938 (horticulturist U.S. Bot. Gard.,
	Washington D.C. 1842-1852).
Gray, J.L., Letters A. Gray 404, 423. 1893.
Haskell, D.C., Bull. New York Public Library 44: 93-112. 1940, 45: 69-90, 507-532, 821-850
	(portr. opp. p. 838). 1941, 46: 103-150. 1942 (main bibl. Expl. Exp.).
Hughes, K.W., Contr. bibl. Oregon bot., Oregon State Coll. 15. 1940.
Johnson, D.E., Huntia 6(1): 21. 1985 (no. 38; info. on history of Berlin bot. gard. ca. 1836).
Maiden, J., J. Proc. R. Soc. N.S.W. 42: 93. 1908 (visit NSW 1839).
Maloney et al., Calif. hist. Soc. Quart. 24: 321-342. Dec 1945 (California journey, repr. of
	B's journal 1-28 Oct 1841; A. Eastwood, list of plants).

HEADING: BRADE

McVaugh, R., Edward Palmer 10. 1959.
Meehan, T., Gard. Monthly 26: 375-376. 1884 (portr.).
Rodgers, A.D., John Torrey 337 (index nine entries). 1942.

	36, 40-41, 197-198, 234-236, 237, 238, 240. 1988.

*Brade, Alexander Curt (1881-1971), German (Niederlausitz) botanist, educated at the
Real-Progymnasium at Forst and at the Königl. preussische Baugewerkschule at Goerlitz,
Schlesien, active in the building trade 1902-1907, at the same time interested in botany, in
contact with the Berlin botanical professors Kny, Sorauer and Wittmack, went to Costa Rica
to collect botanical material 1908-1910, settled in Brazil, building engineer in São Paulo 1910,
settled at a farm in Iguape (S. Paulo) until 1928, 1928-1933 associated with the Museu
nacional Rio de Janeiro, id. at the Inst. Biol. Vegetal as assistant in the Botanical Garden
1933-1938, subsequently biologist at the Serviço Florestal until 1952. (<em>Brade</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: RB. - Further material in AMES, B, BR, F, HH(A, GH), IAC, L,
MO, NY, PH, POM, R, S, SP, U, US.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 237 (b. 19 Jun 1881, Forst); Bossert p. 49; Hortus
3: 1189; IF suppl. 3: 202, 4: 314; IH 2: 92, 109, 114; Kew 1: 334-336; TL-2/1: 300 and see
indexes; Urban-Berl. p. 319; Zander ed. 10, p. 639, ed. 11, p. 726.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Begonian 38: 242. Oct 1971 (obit.).
Ascherson, P.F.A., Verh. Bot. Ver. Prov. Brandenburg 50: xiv-xv. 1909.
Brade, A.C., Lebenslauf (typewritten statement sent to W.F.. Mattick, ca. 1961; copy B).
Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world 365/205b. 1984.
Lellinger, D.B., Amer. Fern J. 62(1): 23. 1972.
Markgraf, F., Bot. Jahrb. 93(1): 1-8. 1973 (obit., itin. Costa Rica 1908-1910).
Mattick, W.F., Willdenowia 6(2): 211-214. 1971 (account of B's career, portr., with a note
	by Th. Eckardt on B's death 19 Jul 1971).
Pabst, G.F.J., Taxon 16: 161-167. 1967 (biogr., bibl., portr.); Bradea 1: 69-72. 1971 (further
	bibl. info.).
Paes, L.E., Willdenowia 8: 85, 87, 88. 1977 (on German botanists in Brazil).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Bradea</em> Stanley ex Brade 1932 (ING 1: 232. 1979); (journal): <em>Bradea</em>, Boletin do
Herbarium Bradeanum. Rio de Janeiro, vol. 1- (1969-).

22.491. Die <em>Farnflora der Umgebung der Stadt São Paulo</em> ... São Paulo (... Rua 15 Novembre)
1920. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1920, cover-t.p., p. [39]-61. <em>Copies</em>: B, L. - Reprinted and to be cited from Z. Deut.
	Ver. Wiss. Kunst São Paulo 1: 39-61. 1920.

PAGE: 5
HEADING: BRAIN

Braendlein, Karl (1880-?), German (Bavarian) chemist, educated at the Gymnasium of
Schweinfurt 1889-1898, studied chemistry at the universities of München and Erlangen as
well as at the München Polytechnikum, examination for teaching chemistry 1903, on active
service at München 1903-1904, subsequently teacher at various private schools, worked on
his thesis at the University of Erlangen 1905-1906, Dr. phil. Erlangen 1906. (<em>Braendlein</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 238 (b. 25 Apr 1880); Kew 1: 337.

22.500. <em>Systematisch-anatomische Untersuchung des Blattes der Samydaceen</em> Bentham-Hooker.
Inaugural-Dissertation zur Erlangung der Doktorwürde der hohen philosophischen Fakultät
der Friedrich-Alexanders-Universität Erlangen ... Amorbach (Gottlob Volkhardt'sche Druckerei)
1907. Oct. (<em>Syst.-anat. Unters. Samyd.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1 Nov 1906 (date of defense thesis; Nat. Nov. Dec (1) 1907), p. [1]-69, [70-73]. <em>Copies</em>:
	G, L, NSUB/GOET.

Braeucker (Bräucker), Theodor (1815-1882), German (Westphalian) teacher and botanist
at Bremen, interested in Rosa and Rubus. (<em>Braeucker</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (large colls. Rosa, Rubus, types, rd. 1885). - Herbarium offered
for sale Bot. Centralbl. 22(21): Anzeigen. 18-22 Mai 1885 (partly bought by B).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 534 (b. 1 Apr 1815, Halver, Westph., d. 3 Mai 1882,
Derschlag, Westph.); Barnhart 1: 238; BM 1: 220; IH 2: 92 (coll. at B); Kew 1: 337; Tucker
1: 105; Urban-Berl. p. 332.

22.501. <em>292 Deutsche</em>, vorzugsweise rheinische <em>Rubus-Arten</em> und Formen zum sicheren
Erkennen analytisch angeordnet und beschrieben ... Berlin (Verlag von Adolf Stubenrauch)
1882. Oct. (<em>292 Rubus-Arten</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr-Jun 1882 (Bot. Centralbl. 17-21 Jul 1882, Bot. Zeit. 30 Jun 1882, ÖBZ 1 Aug
	1882, Bull. Soc. bot. France Sep-Oct 1882), cover-t.p., p. [i]-iv, [v], [1]-112. <em>Copies</em>: G, L.
<em>Ref</em>.: Warnstorf, C., Bot. Centralbl. 11(29): 86. 1882.

22.502. <em>Deutschlands wilde Rosen</em>, 150 Arten und Formen, zum leichteren Erkennen und
Bestimmen angeordnet und beschrieben ... Berlin (Verlag von Adolf Stubenrauch) 1882. Oct. (<em>Deutschl. wilde Rosen</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr-Jun 1882 (Bot. Zeit. 30 Jun 1882), cover-t.p., p. [i]-viii, [1]-78, 79-80, adv. <em>Copies</em>:
	B, G, L.
<em>Ref</em>.: Kempf, H., ÖBZ 32: 306-307. 1 Sep 1882 (rev.).

Brain, Charles K. (fl. 1930-1942), British botanist and collector in Southern Rhodesia. (<em>C.K.
Brain</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: SRGH (4000) and material at the Rhodesian [h.t. Zimbabwe] Dept.
of Agriculture herb. at Mount Makulu; further material at FHO, K, PRE.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: IH 2: 92; Kew 1: 338; LS suppl. 3518.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Exell, A.W. and G.A. Hayes, Kirkia 6(1): 89. 1967 (coll. Fl. Zambesiaca).
White, F., C.R. AETFAT 4: 195. 1962 (coll. at Dept. Agr. herb. at Mount Makulu, Zimbabwe).

Herald Office) 1934. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Mai 1934 (date on p. 51), p. [i], 51-96. <em>Copy</em>: U. - Reprinted and to be cited from Proc.
	Rhodesia Sci. Ass. 33: 51-96. 1934.

PAGE: 6
HEADING: BRAINERD

Brainerd, Ezra (1844-1924), American clergyman and botanist, trained for the ministry at
Andover Theological Seminary, cand. minister 1868, professor at Middlebury College,
Vermont 1868, idem professor in rhetoric, English literature, mathematics and physics 1880,
president of Middlebury College 1885-1908, student of the flora of Vermont, especially
interested in Viola. (<em>Brainerd</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MID (herbarium); further material at BUF, HH, K, MICH, MIN, MO,
NY, PH (Viola), US, VT, WELC.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 239 (further refs.); BL 1: 217; Ewan ed. 1: 80,
130, 245; Hortus 3: 1189; IH 2: 92; Kew 1: 338; NI 221nc; NW p. 41; Rehder 1: 317, 2: 300;
TL-2/see indexes; Tucker 1: 105.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 66(2) (Beibl.): (118). 1926 (d.).
Barnhart, J.H., Amer. Fern J. 15(4): 127-128. 1926 (obit.).
Brainerd Baird, V., Madroño 1(12): 185-186. 1928 (coll. trips in California 1897 and 1915).
Day, M.A., Rhodora 3: 206-207. 1901.
Eggleston, W.W., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 55: 91-104. 1928 (biogr., portr.).
Howe, M.H., J. New York Bot. Gard. 26(301): 12-13. 1925 (obit., d. 8 Dec 1924, Middlebury,
	Vermont).
Stieber, M.T. et al., Huntia 4(1): 61. 1981 (letter to S.M. Tracy at HU).
Sutton, S.B., Charles Sprague Sargent 293, 294, 296. 1970.
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 192. 1905 (b. St. Albans, Vermont, 17 Dec 1844).

22.504. <em>Flora of Vermont</em>; a list of the ferns and seed plants growing without cultivation ...
Burlington (Vermont State Board Agric. Report) 1900. Oct. (<em>Fl. Vermont</em>).

<em>Co-authors</em>: Lewis Ralph Jones (1864-1915), Willard Webster Eggleston (1863-1935).
<em>Publ</em>.: 15 Dec 1900 (in text), p. [i]-viii, [1]-113. <em>Copies</em>: HH, MO. - Issued as Vermont State
	Board Agric. Rep. 20(4). 1900, also as Contributions to the botany of Vermont VIII.
<em>Ref</em>.: Howe, M.A., Torreya 1: 10-12. 29 Jan 1901 (rev.).

Club ... 1910. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 30 Nov 1910 (in journal), p. 523-528, <em>pl. 34-35</em> (uncol. draw.). <em>Copy</em>: BKL. - Reprinted
	and to be cited from Bull. Torrey bot. Club 37(11): 523-528, <em>pl. 34-35.</em> 1910.

22.506. <em>Blackberries of New England</em>, their classification ... Burlington (Free Press Printing
Company) 1920. Oct. (<em>Blackberries N. Engl.</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: Arne Kristopher Peitersen (1884-1924).
<em>Publ</em>.: Jun 1920 (date on cover-t.p.), cover-t.p., p. [1]-84, <em>pl. 1-4</em> (uncol. phot.). <em>Copies</em>: BKL,
	L. - Issued as Bull. Vermont Agric. Exper. State 217, 1920.

22.507. <em>Violets of North America</em> ... Vermont Agricultural Experiment Station ... 1921. Oct. (<em>Violets N. Amer.</em>).

HEADING: A. BRAND

*Brand, August (1863-1930), German (Berlin born) classic philologist, studied at Bonn and
Berlin, classical teacher at Frankfurt a. O. 1885-1910, "Studienrat" at the Gymnasium at
Sorau, in his spare time botanist, collaborator of Engler e.g. for the Pflanzenreich. (<em>Brand</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (types; some herbarium material collected by him as well); further
material at M (Lich.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 240; BFM see no. 10; BJI 1: 6, 2: 17-18; BM 1:
120; CSP 13: 763; DTS 6(4): 118-119; Hortus 3: 1189; IH 2: 92; Kew 1: 339; Langman p.
152; MW p. 51, 52; NW p. 41; RS p. 76; TL-2/1: 302 and see indexes; Zander ed. 10, p. 639,
ed. 11, p. 726-727.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 70(2) (Beibl.): (157). 1931 (d. at Sorau, 17 Sep 1930); Verh. bot.
	Ver. Prov. Brandenburg 71: 1. 1931 (d.).
Brand, A., Herbarium 1908(6): 41 ("Zusammenstellung systematischer Sammlungen").
Harms, H., Fedde Repert. sp. nov. 28: 322. 1930 (obit., b. 19 Aug 1863, Berlin, d. 17 Sep
	1930, Sorau).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) and (2) see TL-2/1: 302.

bot. Gart. Mus. Berlin-Dahlem 55: 172. 4 Apr 1914.

Brand, Donald (1915-x), Botanist, born 6 Mar 1915 in Chiclayo, Peru, at the University of
Texas, Department of Geography, collected in Northwest Chihuahua and in Sonora (Mexico)
1929-1931 and 1934-1936. (<em>Don. Brand</em>).

*Brandegee, Mary Katherine (Layne, later Curran) (1844-1920), American (California)
botanist and plant collector, born in W. Tennessee, from 1853 in California, early schooling
at a seminary in Folsom, Calif., married Hugh Curran (Irish) 1866-1874, came to San
Francisco 1875, studied medicine at the University of California 1875-1878, M.D. 1878, took
interest in botany from 1879, curator of the herbarium of the California Academy of Sciences
1883, married Townsend Stith Brandegee 1889, the couple moved to San Diego 1894 setting
up their own botanical library and herbarium, returned to Berkeley 1906 continuing botani-
zing without official appointment. (<em>K. Brandegee</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Most collections now at UC together with those of her husband.
Further material at B, CAS, DS, E, HH(A, GH); K, L, MO, NMC, NY, PH, POM, US, WELC.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 240; BL 1: 166; Hortus 3: 1189; IH 2: 93; Kew
1: 339; NW p. 41; Rehder 5(index): 114; TL-2/1: 302-303; Tucker 1: 105; Urban-Berl. p.
332; Zander ed. 10, p. 639, ed. 11, p. 727.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Abir-Am, P.G. and D. Outram, eds., Uneasy careers and intimate lives. Women in
	science 1789-1979. 84, 85, 91. 1987.
Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 55(34): 256. 1893 (curator herb. CAS, editor of "Zoe").
Bonta, M.M., Women in the field, America's College Station, Texas 1991 (see index).
Cantelow, E.D. and H.C., Leafl. W. Bot. 8: 86. 1957 ("A remarkable woman", epon. <em>Lupinus
	Layneae</em>, sic).
Crosswhite, F.S. and C.D., Desert plants 7(3): 128-139, 158-162. 1985 (detailed account, portr.).
Dupree, H. and M.L. Gade, <em>in</em> E.T. James et al., Notable American women 1607-1950. 1:
	228-229. 1971 (detailed account, further refs.).
Ewan, J., Not so wild a Fantasy, typescript, 4 p. 1957 copies with J. Ewan and FAS (rebuttal
	to Herre, A.W.C.T. s.d.; see also J. Ewan 1942); Amer. Midland Natural. 27: 772-789.
	1942 (critical evaluation of K. Brandegee in her botanical relations and methods).
Ewan, J. et al., Leafl. W. Bot. 7(3): 55, 58, 59. 1953 (botany at CAS); A century of progress
	in the natural sciences 1853-1953: 1-63. 1955.

HEADING: T.S. BRANDEGEE

*Brandegee, Townsend Stith (1843-1925), American botanist and civil engineer with
Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Rail Road and Denver and South Park Rail Road, county
surveyor of Fremont Company, Colorado 1871-1878, assistant topographer and botanical
collector with the Hayden Survey, for many years honorary curator of the herbarium of the
University of California, married its curator of botany, M.K. Curran (Layne). (<em>Brandegee</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UC (orig. herb. 86.825 specimens); further material at B (Flora of
Lower Calif.), CAS, COLO, DS, F, HH(A, GH), I, L, MICH, MIN, MO, NA, NMC, NY,
PH, POM, QK, US, VT, WELC, WRSL (Lich.). - For his mosses distributed by NY see G.
Sayre (1975).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 240 (b. 16 Feb 1843, Berlin, Conn., d. 7 Apr
1925, Berkeley, Calif.); BJI 1: 6; BL 1: 150, 166, 167, 168, 2: 18; BM 1: 221; Bossert p. 50;
CSP 9: 329, 12: 112, 13: 763; Ewan ed. 1: 169-170, ed. 2: 25-26 (main source); Hortus 3:
1189; IH 2: 93; Kew 1: 339; Langman p. 153-154; NAF 28B(2): 321, ser. 2. 2: 152, ser. 2.

*Brandes, Wilhelm (1834-1916), German (born in Hildesheim) pharmacist and botanist,
educated at the Gymnasium Andreanum in Hildesheim, sometime with his father in the
Löwenapotheke, studied at the University of Göttingen, state pharmacist examination in
Hannover 1858, further studies at the University of Heidelberg, assumed the direction of his
father's pharmacy 1860, "Revisor" of the pharmacies in the Hildesheim area 1867, assuming
as well the Hannover Andreae &amp; Co. pharmacy until 1892, Medizinal-Rat 1900, Dr. h.c.
Göttingen 1914. (<em>W. Brandes</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HAN.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 240; BFM 21, 28, 29; BM 1: 221; CSP 13: 765;
IH 2: 93; Kew 1: 340; Rehder 1: 390; TL-2/1: 304; Tucker 1: 106.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 35: (182). 1917 (d. 8 Jul 1916).
Engelke, C., 6-11 Jahresber. Niedersächs. bot. Ver. 1913-1918: [3-4]. 1919 (obit., b. 2 Apr
	1834, Hildesheim, d. 8 Jul 1916, Hermannsburg).
Roth, E., Bot. Centralbl. 76(44/45): 196. 26 Oct 1898 (rev. of his Flora (1897), see TL-2/703).
Seeland, H., Mitt. Herm. Roemer-Mus. Hildesheim 40: 3, 28, 34, 44, 46. 1936.
Wagenitz, G., Göttinger Biologen 1737-1945: 36. 1988.

HEADING: BRANDIS

*Brandis, [Sir] Dietrich (1824-1907), German botanist and forester, born in Bonn, studied
natural sciences at Copenhagen 1843, continuing in Bonn and Göttingen, Dr. phil. Bonn 1848
(chemistry), botanical teachers J.E. Schouw in Copenhagen and A. Grisebach in Göttingen,
habil. Bonn 1848 for botany and plant chemistry, superintendent of forests in the province
of Burma 1856-1862, forestry advisor with the government of India, Calcutta, "inspector-ge-
neral of forests" to the government of India 1864-1883, returned to Bonn in retirement, L.L.D.
Edinburgh 1889, worked on his <em>Indian trees</em> at Kew 1901-1906. (<em>Brandis</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HBG, important material also at K, further material at BONN, CAL,
DD, FI, GOET, HH(A), M (lich.), MEL, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 6(2): 446, 12(3): 60; Backer p. 80-81; Barnhart 1: 241;
BB p. 43; BJI 1: 7, 2: 18; BM 1: 222, 6: 120; Bossert p. 50; CSP 1: 572, 7: 242, 13: 765;
Desmond p. 85; DNB suppl. 2(1): 217; Hortus 3: 1189; IH 2: 93; Jackson p. 526 (index);
Kew 1: 340-341; KR p. 100; LS 3740-3741; Morren ed. 2, p. 39; NI 224-225; PR 1084-1085;
Rehder 5(index): 114-116; TL-2/1: 304-305 and see indexes; Tucker 1: 106, 673; Zander ed.
10, p. 639, ed. 11, p. 727.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Aderhold, R., Gen.-Reg. Bot. Zeit. 1-50: 11-12. 1895 (2 titles).
Anon., ÖBZ 43: 300. 1893 (appt. professor at Bonn); Nat. Nov. 29: 321. 1907 (d.); Torreya
	7(7): 156. 1907 (d.).

Brandt, Ernst Friedrich Wilhelm (1821-?), German (Neustadt-Magdeburg) botanist, edu-

*Brandt, Johann Friedrich (1802-1879), German (Jüterborgh, Brandenburg) botanist and
zoologist, educated at the Gymnasium of Jüterborgh and the Lyceum at Wittenberg, studied
classics at the University of Berlin 1821, later zoology and botany ib., M.D., surgeon and
accoucheur 1826, worked with Ratzeburg 1826-1831 e.g. on the plants of the Prussian
Pharmacopoeia, assistant, later director of the zoological Museum, St. Petersburg from 1831.
(<em>Brandt</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; if any at LE.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 47: 182-184; Barnhart 1: 241 (b. 25 Mai 1802,
Jüterborgh, d. 3/15 Jul 1879 Merikullia, Estonia); BM 1: 222-224, 6: 120; Bossert p. 50; CSP
1: 572-577, 6: 603, 7: 243-245, 9: 331, 13: 766-767; DSB 2: 422-423; Frank 3(Anh.): 13;
Jackson p. 302; Langman p. 346; LS 3742; MW p. 52; NI 226; NW p. 52; Plesch p. 155, 251;
PR 1089-1091, ed. 1: 1234-1237; Quenstedt p. 55; Ratzeburg p. 72-76; Rehder 1: 377, 3: 56,
73, 397; TL-2/1: 305-306 and see indexes; TR 169; Tucker 1: 107, 251, 767; Zander ed. 10,
p. 639, ed. 11, p. 727.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 3: 30. 1855 (cognomen Leopoldina: Daubenton); Das fünfzig-
	jährige Doctorjubileum des Akademikers Geh. J.F. Brandt, St. Petersburg, 1877, 105 p.;

Brandt, Max (1884-1914), German (born at Rüsselsheim am Main), educated at Ditmar-
schen, the second Lyceum at Hannover and the Gymnasium at Schleswig and id. Lüneburg,
matriculation 1904, studied botany and geology at Göttingen, Bonn and Berlin, military
service 1904-1905, ult. Lieutenant with the first Garde-Regiment in Potsdam, student, later
assistant with Engler at the Botanical Museum, Dr. phil. Berlin 1911, collected in Spain and
Morocco 1913, on active service 1914, fell in S. Poland nr. Czczeczow 29 Nov 1914. (<em>M.
Brandt</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B. - Further material in L, S.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 241 (b. 17 Sep 1884, Rüsselsheim a. M., d. 29
Nov 1914, killed in battle); Hortus 3: 1189; IH 2: 93; Kew 1: 341; Urban-Berl. p. 69, 79, 332;
Zander ed. 10, p. 639, ed. 11, p. 727.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Torreya 15(3): 59-60. 15 Apr 1915 (obit., quotation from Evening Post and
	Berl. Tageblatt).

	Rüsselsheim, d. 29 Nov 1914, Czczeczow, S. Poland; list of publ., portr.).
Zepernick, B., and F.K. Timler, Englera 1: 32-33. 1979.

Brandt, [Andreas] Wilhelm [Heinrich] (1879-1929), German pharmacist, born at Secken-
heim, Baden, educated at schools at Rothenfelde nr. Osnabrück and Schalke nr. Gelsenkir-
chen, at gymnasia at Schalke and Elberfeld, pharmaceutical apprenticeship at Barmen
1898-1900, stage at Elberfeld 1901-1903, id. Stettin 1903-1904, pharmacist at Elberfeld
1904-1911, studied again in Berlin 1913, Dr. phil. University Berlin 1915, botany with Engler
and Gilg, assistant at the Botanical Institute, Frankfurt a. M. 1916, habil. Bot. &amp; Pharmacogn.
1917, extraord. professor for pharmacognosy 1919-1927. (<em>W. Brandt</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Egle, K. and G. Rosenstock, Gesch. Bot. Frankfurt a. M. 34. 1966.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Editor with G. Schellenberg of iv. 2. Ergänzungsband of <em>Köhler's
Medizinal-Pflanzen in naturgetreuen Abbildungen mit kurz erläuterndem Texte</em>. 1914.

*Brândză, Dimitrie (1846-1895), Roumanian botanist, founder of Roumanian botany,
founder of the Botanical Garden in Bucarest as well as of the Botanical Institute with
herbarium, museum and library, the Natural History Museum under the aegis of the Rouma-

*Brândză, Marcel Alex (1868-1934), Roumanian botanist and entomologist, lecturer in
botany at the Pharmaceutical Faculty and curator of the cryptogamic collections of the
Botanical Institute of the University at Bucarest, specialist in Myxomycetes. (<em>Brândză</em>).

Branner, John Casper (1850-1922), American geologist and botanist, born in Newmarket,
Tenn., studied at Cornell University, grad. 1874, geologist on the Imperial Geological
Commission, Brazil 1875-1877, topographical geologist at the Geological Survey of Penn-
sylvania 1883-1885, professor of geology at the University of Indiana 1885-1892, State
geologist of Arkansas 1887-1892, professor of geology at Leland Stanford Junior University
from 1892. (<em>Branner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY (40, fossil.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 241 (b. 4 Jul 1850, d. 1 Mar 1922, further refs.);

Stieber, M.T. et al., Huntia 4(1): 61. 1981 (2 letters to F.V. Coville).

Brannon, Melvin Amos (1865-1950), American botanist and educator, born at Lowell,
Indiana, died 26 Mar 1950 in Gainesville, Florida, Wabash College A.B. 1889, A.M. 1890,
studied at Marine Biology College, Woods Hole, Mass. 1891-1894, Ph.D. Chicago 1912,
dean of the School of Medicine 1899-1911, id. Liberal Arts 1911-1914 at University of Notre
Dame, president University of Idaho 1914-1917, president Beloit Coll., Wisc. 1917-1923,
Chancellor Montana 1923-1933. (<em>Brannon</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: F (500).

Branscheidt, Paul (1893-x), German botanist, born 28 Aug 1893 in Derschlag, Rheinland,
"Volksschule" also in Derschlag, secondary school in Bergneustadt (Rheinland) 1904,
"Oberrealschule" in Gummersbach 1908-1912, at the University of Göttingen 1912-1914,
again at Göttingen 1916, Dr. phil. Göttingen 1917, "Dozent" at the University of Würzburg
1936, as professor 1939 and also as director of the "Institut für angewandte Botanik".
(<em>Branscheidt</em>).

tut für angewandte Botanik").

Branth, Jakob Severin Deichmann (1831-1917), Danish botanist (lichenologist), studied
theology and botany at Copenhagen University, cand. Theol. 1857, travelled and worked in
Germany, Switzerland and Italy 1857, private teacher at Bregentved until 1861; in charge of
a highschool in Tønder 1861-1864, catechist at Selskør 1866, vicar at Elling-Tolne 1871-
1880, at Ovsted-Taaning 1880-1908, in retirement living at Kolding. (<em>Branth</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: C (lich.), further material (also lichens) at B, KIEL, LE.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 242; BM 1: 224; IH 2: 93; Jackson p. 333; Kew

Brass, Leonard John (1900-1971), Australian botanist, assistant in the Queensland Herba-
rium 1918-1919, for some years engaged in cattle ranching activities in N. Queensland and
the Northern Territory of Australia, on expedition to Papua for Arnold Arb. 1932-1933, id.
British Solomon Islands, with the Archbold expedition of the American Museum of Natural
History 1933, in 1946 for the New York Botanical Garden on the Vernay expedition to
Nyasaland. (<em>Brass</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HH (orig.), further material at B, BM, BO, BR, BRI, F, K, L, NY,
NSW, P, S, SING, U, UPS, US, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 242 (b. 27 Mai 1900, Toowoomba, Queensl.);
IH 2: 93, 534; Kew 1: 342-343; SK 1: 76-78 (main source), 4: 106, cli, clii.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Garden J. 12: 197-198. 1962 (Sc. D. h.c. by Florida State University);
	Principes 15(4): 138. 1971; Fl. Males. Bull. 26: 1993. 1972.
Deusen, H.M. van, N. Queensl. Nat. 39(156): 2-3. 1971.
Hall, N., Botanists of the Eucalypts, Melbourne 38. 1978.
Hunt Institution, Biogr. Dict. Bot. portr. coll. 50. 1972 (d. 29 Aug 1971).
MacLeod, R. and P.F. Rehbock, Nature in its greatest extent, Honolulu, Hawaii 110. 1990.
Perry, L.M., J. Arnold Arb. 52(4): 695-698. 1971 ("appreciation", portr.).
Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 298. 1 Mai 1975.

22.582. Notes on the <em>vegetation</em> of the fly and <em>Wassi Kussa Rivers</em>, British New Guinea ...
Reprinted ... from Journal of the Arnold Arboretum ... 1938. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 27 Apr 1938 (in journal), cover-t.p., p. 174-190, <em>pl. 221-223</em> (uncol. phot.). <em>Copy</em>: L.
	 - Reprinted and to be cited from J. Arnold Arb. 19(2): 174-190, <em>pl. 221-223.</em> 1938.

*Braun, Alexander [Carl Heinrich] (1805-1877), German botanist, born in Regensburg, at
the Lyceum of Karlsruhe 1816, started collecting plants 1816, published in "Flora" 1821, at
the University of Heidelberg 1824-1827 studying medicine and botany with Louis Agassiz
and Carl Friedrich Schimper who also studied botany, at the University of Tübingen
1827-1829, Dr. phil. ib. 1829, professor of botany and zoology at the Polytechnic School in
Karlsruhe 1832-1846, at the same time also assistant, later director of the Karlsruhe natural
history museum, professor of botany at the University of Freiburg i. Breisgau 1846-1850, id.
in Giessen 1850, ultimately professor of botany at the University of Berlin and director of
the Berlin Botanical Garden 1851. (<em>A. Braun</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (main herbarium, partly destroyed), early collections at LZ
(destroyed), further material at AUT, BERN, BM, BUC, C, CGE, CLF, DBN, E, F, FB, G,
GI, GOET, H, HAL, HBG, HH(FH), K, KBG, KR, L, LD, LE, M, MANCH, NCY, NY, OXF,

PAGE: 24
HEADING: A. BRAUN

REG, PC, PH, S, SI, UPS, W, WRSL.
<em>Note (1</em>): See TL-2/1: 307 for further info, including <em>Die Characeen Europas</em> (exsiccatae).
<em>Note (2)</em>: Braun's herbarium was bought by the Prussian govt. for his institute after his death
(see Flora 61(1): 16. 1878) at 21.000 Mark.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 47: 163-165; AG 1: 40, 4: 52, 5(1): 270, 12(3): 573;
Ainsworth p. 117, 236, 274; Andrews ed. 2. 241; Barnhart 1: 242 (further refs.); BJI 1: 7; BL
1: 34; BM 1: 225-226; Bossert p. 50; Christiansen p. 28 (index); Clokie p. 137; CSP 1:
583-585, 7: 248, 12: 116; De Toni 1: xvi, 2: xv; DNB 2: 5489; DSB 2: 425-427; DTS 1: 30,
6(4): 19; Frank 3(Anh.): 13-14; GR p. 7; GR, cat. p. 61; Hegi 1: 23; Hortus 3: 1189; IF p. 684;
IH 2: 94, 726; Jackson p. 526 (index); Kew 1: 343-344; Langman p. 155; Lasègue p. 566
(index); LS 3754-3772; Moebius p. 448 (index); Morren ed. 2, p. 1; MW p. 52; NDB 2: 548;

collector, in Cameroon 1887-1888 and 1891, on Madagascar 1892/93. See Leopoldina 29:
56-57. 1893 and his <em>Botanischer Bericht über die Flora von Kamerun</em>, Mitt. Forschungsreis.
u. Gelehr. Deut. Schutzgeb. 2: 141-176. 1889.

*Braun, Carl [Karl] Friedrich Wilhelm (1800-1864), German (Bayreuth-born) palaeobo-
tanist, at pharmacy in Regensburg 1814 [sic]-1819, employed with a pharmacy in Salzburg
1819-1821, turned to botany with Hoppe, worked with Sternberg in Praha 1821, studied
physiology and natural history at Erfurt 1821-1823, pharmacist at Regensburg in his father's
pharmacy 1823-1831, teacher at Bayreuth at an agricultural college 1833 as well as continuing
his palaeontological activity. (<em>Braun</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at REG; most of his palaeobotanical material at WB
(584 nos.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 3: 269-271 (bibl.); Andrews ed. 2: 241-242; Barnhart
1: 243; BM 1: 226; CSP 1: 585; DTS 1: xviii, 30, 6(4): 17, 25; Hortus 3: 1189; Jackson p.

PAGE: 33
HEADING: H. BRAUN

177, 180, 185; PR 1109; Quenstedt p. 56; Ratzeburg 1: 80; Saccardo 1: 37-38; TL-2/1: 310
and see indexes.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Flora 3(2): 638. 1820 (in Salzburg), 12(2): 493. 1829 (coll. Tirol); 47: 424.
	1864 (d.).
Baillon, H.E., Dict. bot. 1: 490. 1878.
Haidinger, W.K. von, Jahrb. geol. Reichsanstalt Wien 14, Verh.: 147-148. 1864.
Hausmann zu Stetten, F.v., Fl. Tirol 1174. 1854.
Ilg, W., Hoppea 42: 310, 319. 1984 (member Regensb. bot. Ges. 1837).
Popp, O., ÖBZ 14: 313-320. 1864 (main biogr., b. Bayreuth 1 Dec 1800, d. ib. 20 Jun 1864).
Schlechtendal, D.F.L. von, Bot. Zeit. 22: 232. 1864 (called himself Friedrich Braun).
Ratzeburg, J.I.C., Forstwiss. Schriftsteller-Lexikon 80. 1874.
Stieber, M.T. et al., Huntia 4(1): 62. 1981 (plant label, mss.).
Walther, A., ÖBZ 14: 224. 1864 (brief obit.).
Weiss, Bayreuth als Stätte alter erdgeschichtlicher Entdeckungen. Bayreuth 1937, p. 24-32
	(portr.).

Braun, Ernst (fl. 1933), German (Schömberg, Württemberg) pharmacist, studied at the
University of Basel, Dr. phil. ib. 1933 (<em>E. Braun</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: No further information beyond his thesis.

22.634. Zur <em>Pharmakognosie der Ericaceen und Primulaceen</em>. Anatomie des Laubblattes.
Inaugural-Dissertation zur Erlangung der philosophischen Doktorwürde vorgelegt der Phi-
losophischen Fakultät der Universität Basel von Ernst Braun approb. Apotheker aus Schöm-
berg O.-A. Freudenstadt (Württemberg). Lörrach-Stetten (Buchdruckerei Karl Schahl) 1933.
Oct. (<em>Pharmakogn. Eric. Primul.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1933 (Nat. Nov. Dec 1933), cover, p. [i-viii], 1-102, <em>1 table</em>. <em>Copies</em>: G, L.

Braun, Heinrich (1851-1920), Austrian botanist, alderman at Vienna. (<em>Heinr. Braun</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W(9000), further material at B (herb. Ullepitsch), GOET, HH(A),
IAC, L, LE, PRC. - <em>Exsiccatae</em> in M. Willkomm, <em>Algen</em> 1890, see Bot. Centralbl. 44(52):
432. 24 Dec 1890.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 95; Barnhart 1: 243 (b. 13 Feb 1851, Wien, d. 3 Sep 1920,
Wien); BM 1: 226, 769; DTS 1: 30, 6(4): 80; Futak-Domin p. 122, 233; Hegi 4(2): 1019; Hortus 3:
1189; IH 2: 94; Kew 1: 344; KR p. 101; Morren ed. 10, p. 30; Rehder 5(index): 117; Tucker 1: 108.

Braun, Carl Philipp Johann Georg (1870-1935), German (born Biebrich am Rhein)
pharmacist and botanist, Dr. phil. Basel 1900, employed at the Biological-Agricultural
Institute in Amani, Tanganyika, ultimately as head of the "Biologische Reichsanstalt für
Land- und Forstwirtschaft" ib. (<em>C.P. Braun</em>).

Braun, [Emma] Lucy (1889-1971), American (Cincinnati, Ohio born) botanist, of a family
of German-French (mother), English (father) descent, educated at Cincinnati public schools,
studied at the University of Cincinnati, B.A. 1910, M.A. geol. 1912, Ph.D. bot. 1914, assistant
in geology 1910-1913, id. botany 1914-1917, instructor in botany 1917-1923, assistant
professor 1923-1926, associate professor of botany 1927-46, id. plant ecology 1946-1948,
emeritus 1948-1971, all at Cincinnati. (<em>Lucy Braun</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CINC, further material at HH(A, GH), MO, NY, PH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 243; BL 2: 207; GR p. 206; Hortus 3: 1189; IF
suppl. 4, p. 314; IH 2: 94.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Ohio J. Sci. 71(4): 247-248. 1971 (obit.).
Browne, E.T., Trans. Kentucky Acad. Sci. 25: 80. 1964.
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 122, 127. 1969.
Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world 149/121a, 152/122b. 1984.
Stieber, M.T. et al., Huntia 4(1): 62. 1981 (archival material at HU), 4(2): 153. 1982.
Stuckey, R.L., Mss. biography 4 p. s.d. (main source for our caption, b. 19 Apr 1889, d. 5
	Mar 1971); Mich. Bot. 12: 83-106. 1973; <em>in</em> Notable American Women, Harvard Univ.
	Press 102-103. 1980; E. Lucy Braun: Ohio's foremost woman botanist, collection of
	biogr.-account, maps, photos, for E. Lucy Braun Symposium 5 Mai 1990. Cincinnati.

<sm>NOTES</sm>: (1) Outside our period: <em>The woody plants of Ohio</em> 1961, facsimile ed. 1969, 362 p.,
see Taxon 20: 187. 28 Feb 1971.
(2) id. <em>Deciduous forests of Eastern North America</em> 1950, facsimile ed. 1964, 586 p., see
Taxon 13: 295. 1964.

HEADING: W. BRAUN

Braun, Waldemar (1883-?), German physician and botanist, Baden-Baden born (18 Jan
1883), educated at the humanistic Gymnasium Rastatt, studied medicine at the universities
of Würzburg, Strassburg and Berlin, med. exam. 1916, Dr. med. Berlin 1919, practicing in
a gynaecological clinic for three years, military physician on active duty 1916-1919, from
1925 dedicating himself to botanical and cytological studies, Dr. phil. Berlin 1930. (<em>W.
Braun</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

22.646. <em>Die Haploidgeneration der Dipsacaceen</em> und ihre Bedeutung für die systematische
Stellung dieser Familie. Inaugural-Dissertation zur Erlangung der Doktorwürde der Hohen
Philosophischen Fakultät der Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität zu Berlin ... Berlin (Druck:
Graphisches Institut Paul Funk) 1929. Qu. (<em>Haploidgen. Dipsac.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1929 (preissued, the actual promotion took place on 4 Jun 1930 with P.N. Schürhoff
	and L. Diels), cover-t.p., p. [1]-45. <em>Copy</em>: B.
<em>Ref</em>.: Krause, K., Bot. Jahrb. 64(Lit.): 30-31. 12 Mar 1931 (rev.).

*Braun-Blanquet, Josias (until 1915 Josias Braun) (1884-1980), Swiss geobotanist, born
in Chur, student at Zürich, originally following a business career, from 1905-1912 also
following geobotanic instructions from Schröter, Brockmann-Jerosch and Rübel, from then
on fully dedicated to geobotany and plant-sociology, studied at Montpellier 1913-1915, Dr.
phil. ib. 1915, habil. Zürich 1923, assistant with Rübel 1915-1922, lecturer 1922-1926, moved
to Montpellier 1926, in charge of the International station for alpine and mediterranean
geobotany (SIGMA) 1927-1980; founder of the French-Swiss school of phytosociology.
(<em>Braun-Blanq</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: SIGMA, further material at B, BERN, BRSL, C, CHUR, GB, LAU,
MPU, RAB, U, W, WAG, WRSL, Z.
<em>Flora rhaetica exsiccata 1</em>: nos. 1-100. Jan 1918, 32 p.p. (schedae).
<em>2</em>: nos. 101-200. 1919, Jahresber. naturf. Ges. Graubündens (id.) 59: 153-181. Mai 1919.
<em>3</em>: nos. 201-300. Mai 1920, id. 60: 1-29. 1921 (id.).
<em>4</em>: nos. 301-400. Jun 1921, id. 60: 169-197. 1921 (id.).
<em>5</em>: nos. 401-500. Jun 1922, id. 61: 15-43. 1922 (id.)
<em>6</em>: nos. 501-600. Jun 1923, id. 62: 71-110. 1923 (id.).

<em>13</em>: nos. 1201-1300. Jun 1938.

Brause, Guido Georg Wilhelm (1847-1922), German (Silesian) soldier and botanist,
educated at the gymnasium at Neisse (Silesia), later at Oppeln, joined the Prussian army,
officer in the German-French war, fought at Metz, Vionville Le Mans 1870-1871, sub-
sequently stationed at Brandenburg a.H. and Potsdam, amateur botanist, after his retirement
1905 in connection with the Botanical Garden and Museum in Berlin as well as with the
Botanical Verein der Provinz Brandenburg, mainly interested in Pteridophyta. (<em>Brause</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 244; BJI 2: 18; IF suppl. 1: 76, 2: 34, 3: 203; Kew
1: 347; KR p. 101; SK 4: cli, 106.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 64(2) (Beibl.): (143). 1923 (d. 17 Dec 1922 Berlin-Steglitz).
Loesener, Th., Notizbl. Bot. Gart. Mus. Berlin-Dahlem 8: 354-356. 1923 (b. 7 Aug 1847,
	Kochanowitz, Siles., d. 17 Dec 1922, Berlin; list of publ.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Polypodiaceae</em>, <em>in</em> R. Pilger, <em>Plantae Uleanae</em> novae vel minus
cognitae, Notizbl. Kön. bot. Gart. Mus. Berlin-Dahlem 6(54): 41. 20 Mar 1914.
(2) <em>Cyatheaceae, Polypodiaceae, Isoëtaceae</em>, <em>in</em> I. Urban, <em>Symb. Ant.</em> 7: 151-156, 156-162.
15 Dec 1911 (with Urban). - See Hedwigia 52(1): (33). 1912 for authorship.
(3) <em>Pteridophyta</em>, <em>in</em> J. Mildbraed, <em>Botanik</em>, Wiss. Erg. Deut. Zentral-Afr. Exp. 1907-1908 2:
1-40. 1910 (with G. Hieronymous, see Hedwigia 50(4) (Beibl.): (158). 30 Dec 1910.
(4) <em>Die Farnpflanzen</em> (Pteridophyta), <em>in</em> G.Lindau, <em>Kryptogamenflora für Anfänger</em> 6(2):
1-108. Berlin (J. Springer) 1914; see rev. G.H. [Hieronymous], Hedwigia 55(1) (Beibl.): (29).
12 Mai 1914.
(5) <em>Pteridophyta</em>, <em>in</em> W. Lorch, <em>Die Torf- und Lebermoose</em> 1914, see TL-2/4982.

22.678. <em>Neue Farne Papuasiens</em>, nebst allgemeinen Bemerkungen über das Vorkommen der
Pteridophyten in Neu-Guinea von R. Schlechter ... Leipzig (Wilhelm Engelmann) 1912. Oct. 

<em>Collector</em>: [Friedrich Richard] Rudolf Schlechter (1872-1925), see TL-2/5: 205-213.
<em>Publ</em>.: 27 Aug 1912 (in journal), cover-t.p., p. [i, recto of 6], [6]-59. <em>Copies</em>: B, L. - Reprinted
	and to be cited from Bot. Jahrb. 49(1): 6-59. 1912. - Preceeded in journal by "Allgemeine
	Bemerkungen über das Vorkommen der Pteridophyten in Neu-Guinea" in Bot. Jahrb.
	49(1): 1-6. 1912.

Bray, William L. (1865-1953), American botanist, born at Burnside, Ill., studied at Cornell
University 1889-1891, A.B. Indiana State University, Lake Forest 1893-1895, M.A. 1894,
at the University of Berlin 1896-1897, at the University of Chicago, obtaining Ph.D. 1896,
instructor in botany at the University of Texas 1897-1898, adj. professor 1898-1901, assoc.
professor 1902-1905, professor 1905-1907, finally professor in botany at Syracuse University
1907. (<em>W.L. Bray</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US (incl. field notes), further material at NY, PH, SUM, TEX.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 244 (b. 19 Sep 1865, Burnside, Ill., d. 25 Mai
1953); BJI 1: 7, 2: 19; IH 2: 94; Rehder 5(index): 118; Tucker 1: 108-109.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Nat. Nov. 19: 517. 1897 (professor bot. Univ. Texas); Deut. bot. Monatsschr.
	16(1): 16. 1898 (appt. prof. bot. Austin); ÖBZ 57: 487. 1907 (prof. bot. Univ. Syracuse).
Barnhart, J.H., J. New York Bot. Gard. 12: 121. 1911 (curr. vit., worked at NYBG 1906).
Correll, D.S. and M.C. Johnston, Manual vasc. pl. Texas 1792. 1970.
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 122. 1969.
Faust, M.E., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 82: 298-300. Jul 1955 (obit., portr., list publ.).
Murrill, W.A, Hist. found. botany Florida 43. 1945.
Stieber, M.T. and A.L. Karg, Huntia 5(3): 196. 1984.
Stieber, M.T. et al., Huntia 4(1): 63. 1981 (letters at HU).

Breakwell, Ernest (1884-?), Australian botanist at the Royal Botanical Gardens Sydney,

*Brébisson, [Louis] Alphonse de (1798-1872), French naturalist, promotor of sciences and
arts of independent means at Falaise, Dépt. Calvados, especially interested in cryptogams,
archeology and photography. (<em>Bréb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CN, diatoms at MPU, PC (8000), AWH and L. - See TL-2/1: 311. -

OS, PH, TL, TO, W, WRSL. - <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Mousses de la Normandie</em>, see MD p. 57-59 and
TL-2/723.

Brebner, George (1855-1904), British botanist (cytologist, algologist), Aberdeen born,
educated at Aberdeen and Stuttgart, attended the Royal College of Science, London, studied
under D.H. Scott ib. 1888, subsequently lecturer on botany at University College, Bristol
until 1904, active in the Bristol Naturalists' Society. (<em>Brebner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (Algae, rd. 1885-1897, 82 micr.-preps. and herb. specim.); further
material at PLY (Dickinson, Phycol. Bull. 1: 11. 1952).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 245; BB p. 43-44; CSP 13: 783; Desmond p. 86;
De Toni 4: ix; IH 2: 94; LS 3784-3785; Moebius p. 209.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1905: 56 (d.); Hedwigia 44(3) (Beibl.): (137). 1905 (d.).
Murray, G., Hist. coll nat. hist. Depts. BM. 1: 136. 1984 (preparations herb. mat.).
Scott, D.H., J. Bot. 43: 60-61. 1905 (obit., d. 23 Dec 1904).

<em>Ref</em>.: Solms-Laubach, H., Bot. Zeit. 16(II): 37-39. 1 Feb 1903 (rev.).

Breda de Haan, Jacob van (1866-1917), Dutch agriculturist, studied at the University of
Leiden, Dr. phil. ib. 1891, employed by the Sugar Experiment Station at Kagok-Tegal,
Semarang 1892, later agricultural inspector in Java, stationed at Buitenzorg (Bogor). (<em>Breda
de Haan</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

*Brefeld, Julius Oscar (1839-1925), German (Telgte nr. Münster in Westfalen) mycologist,
studied pharmacy at the universities of Berlin and Heidelberg, pharmaceutical state exami-
nation at Heidelberg, habilitation at Berlin 1873, sometime private lecturer in botany in
Würzburg, professor of botany at the Forestry Academy at Eberswalde 1878, id. and director
of the Botanical Gardens at Münster 1882, director of the Plant physiological Institute of the
University of Breslau, replacing F. Cohn, because of eye trouble in retirement living in Berlin
as Regierungsrat 1907-1925 (<em>Bref</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (see Willdenowia 2: 783. 1961: "Brefeld, O.: Herbarium.").

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth see index; Barnhart 1: 245; BM 1: 228, 6: 124;
Bossert p. 51; CSP 7: 252, 9: 340-341, 13: 786; DSB 2: 436-438; DTS 1: 33; Frank 3(Anh.):
14; GR p. 66 (b. 19 Aug 1839, d. 7 Jan 1925); Jackson p. 169, 170; Kew 1: 348-349; LS
3794-3831, 31.507-31.509; LS suppl. 3396; Maiwald p. 448 (index); Moebius p. 71, 102,
103, 104, 106, 271, 294; Morren ed. 2, p. 10, ed. 10, p. 15; PR 1125, 10.544; Stevenson p.
1237; TL-2/1: 314-315 and see indexes.

Brehmer, Wilhelm Georg Baptist Alexander von (1883-x), German (born Minden in
Westfalen) botanist, educated at the Viktoria Gymnasium in Potsdam until 1901, studied
pharmacy, examination for assistant pharmacist 1903, studied at the universities of Berlin,
Kiel and again Berlin, state examination for pharmacist 14 Mai 1909, practicing as pharmacist
1909-1911, licensed pharmaceutical practicioner 1911, studied botany at the Friedrich-Wil-
helms-Universität, Berlin 1911-1913, travelled in German-East-Africa 1913, studied at the
Botanical Museum Berlin 1913-1914, scientific assistant ib. 1914-1915, Dr. phil. University
of Berlin 1915, assistant at the Botanical Museum 1918, idem at the Potato Institute and the
Botanical Institute of the University of Berlin 1919-1931, at the Pathological-anatomical
division of the Biologische Reichsanstalt 1931-1940, director of infection research 1940-
1948, at Bad Kreuznach 1948-1950, in charge of Paracelsus-Institute, Nürnberg 1950.
(<em>Brehmer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 246 (b. 24 Jan 1883); BFM 2957; BJI 2: 19; BL
1: 5; LS suppl. 3600; Urban-Berl. p. 67.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Notizbl. Bot. Mus. Gart. Berlin 7: 334 (assistant at B 1 Nov 1915), 399 (on
	active service 30 Mai 1916); Hedwigia 74(1) (Beibl.): (140). 1934 ("Mitglied der Biolo-
	gischen Reichsanstalt").
Lack, H.W. and O. v. Sydow, Willdenowia 13: 415. 1983 (letters at UPS-UB).
Verdoorn, F., Chron. bot. 1: 132. 1935.
Zepernick, B. and F.K. Timler, Englera 1: 34. 1979 (main biogr. source).

22.715. <em>Über eine Glossopterisflora am Ulugurugebirge</em> (Deutsch Ost-Afrika) ... Leipzig und
Berlin (Verlag von Wilhelm Engelmann) 1914. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 16 Jun 1914 (in journal), cover-t.p., p. [399]-411, <em>pl. 2</em> (uncol. phot.). <em>Copy</em>: B. -
	Reprinted and to be cited from Bot. Jahrb. 51(3-4): 399-411, <em>pl. 2.</em> 1914.

22.716. Über die <em>systematische Gliederung</em> und Entwicklung der Gattung <em>Wahlenbergia in

*Breidler, Johann (1828-1913), Austrian architect and botanist, born in Leoben, educated
at the "Volksschule" and a continuation school, "Hauptschule", from 1843-1849 at the
Joanneum (technical college) at Graz, at the Royal School of architecture in Berlin 1849-
1852, architect at Leoben but spending most of his time on botany, working often with Jakob
Juratzka, specializing in bryology, from 1896 living at Graz. (<em>Breidl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Bryological collections at GJO (50.000); phanerogams at PRC. -
Further material at B(general), BP, GOET, GZU, H, LE, PC, P-SA, S, W (lich.; musci), WRSL
(part of general herb.), WU (musci, 3500). - Breidler contributed material to G. Beck et A.
Zahlbruckmer, <em>Kryptogamas exsiccata</em>s, <em>ed. Mus. Palat. Vind.</em>

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 246; BM 1: 229; Bossert p. 51; CSP 13: 787;
DTS 1: 33; IH 2: 95; Morren ed. 10, p. 30; SBC p. 116; TL-2/1: 315; Urban-Berl. p. 295.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., ÖBZ 60: 46. 1910 (moss herb. donation at PRC); Magyar bot. Lapok
	12(10/12): 361-362. 31 Mar 1914.
Glowacki, J., ÖBZ 64(2): 39-43. 1 Feb 1914 (b. 12 Sep 1828, Leoben; d. 24 Jul 1913, Graz;
	main biogr., lists 9 publications); Mitt. naturh. Ver. Steiermark 50: 3-7. 1914 (portr., bibl.).
Lack, H.W. and O. v. Sydow, Willdenowia 13: 415. 1983 (lists letters by B. at UPS-UB), 14:
	449. 1984 (portrait in the Dörfler coll. of portraits).
Schefczik, J. and K. Mecenovic, Mitt. Abt. zool. Bot. Landesmus. Joann. Graz 33: 85-123.
	1969 (on B's material at GJO).
Wagenitz, G., Index coll. princ. herb. Gotting. 31. 1982 (coll. at GOET):
Wettstein, R. von, Lehrkanzel Syst. Bot., deut. Univ. Prag 10. 1899 (part of B's herb.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) J. Breidler and J.B. Förster published Jakob Juratzka, <em>Laubm.-Fl.
Oesterr.-Ung.</em> 1882, see TL-2/3456.
(2) <em>Musci</em>, <em>in</em> G. Beck, <em>Fl. Süd-Bosnien 1</em>, Ann, naturh. Hofmus. Wien 1: 271-325. 1886.

Breindl, Max (fl. 1934), German botanist from Lindenberg i. Allgäu, studied at the Ludwig-
Maximilians-Universität zu München, Dr. phil. ib. 1934, student of M. Hirmer. (<em>Breindl</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: If any at M.

Breistroffer, Maurice [André Frantz] (1910-1986), French botanist at Grenoble, Licensié
ès Sciences naturelles, curator of the Laboratory of Geology at the University of Grenoble
and auxiliary collaborator with the "Centre national de la Recherche scientifique appliquée"
at Grenoble, specialized in geobotany and systematics of the flora of the Dauphiné. (<em>Breistr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GRM (see IH 1, ed. 8, p. 151).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BFM 2315, 2316; BL 2: 634 (index); Hortus 3: 1189; Kew

Fuchs, H.P., Bull. Murith. 109: 124-125. 1991 (b. 15 Jul 1910, Paris, d. 17 Feb 1986,
	Grenoble; biogr.).

a supplement published in Proc. Verb. Soc. Dauph. Étud. Biol. 1937-1941.

Breitfeld, Alexander (1858-?), German botanist, born in Döbeln, Sachsen, educated at the
Kön. Realschule I. Ordnung (i.e. Gymnasium) in Rawitsch, Posen, final examination 1878,

PAGE: 52
HEADING: BREMEKAMP

studied at the universities of Berlin and Breslau (natural sciences), scientific state examination
1884, teaching at the gymnasium of Reichenbach, Schlesien 1884-1885, full teacher at the
Royal Gymnasium at Königshütte O./S., Dr. phil. Univ. Breslau 15 Feb 1888. (<em>A. Breitf.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 246; BJI 1: 7; Rehder 2: 658; Tucker 1: 109.

systematischen Gruppierung und ihrer geographischen Verbreitung. Inaugural-Dissertation,
welche nebst beigefügten Sätzen mit Genehmigung der philosophischen Fakultät der Uni-
versität Breslau zur Erlangung der Doctorwürde am 15. Februar 1888 ... Leipzig (Wilhelm
Engelmann) 1888. Oct. (<em>Bau Blätt. Rhododendr.</em>).

<em>Thesis issue</em>: 15 Feb 1888 (date of defense thesis; Nat. Nov. Apr (3) 1888), p. [1]-29, [30-32].

	<em>pl. 6-7.</em> 27 Mar 1888. - "Lebenslauf" on p. [30]. - Student of Ferdinand Cohn at Breslau.

*Bremekamp, Cornelius Elisa Bertus (1888-1984), Dutch botanist born in Dordrecht,
educated at the gymnasium of his birthtown, studied at the University of Utrecht with F.A.F.C.
Went as his main teacher, Dr. phil. 1912 Utrecht, employed at the Experiment Station of the
Java Sugar industry at Pasuruan 1912-1921, from 1915 also lecturer in biology at Surabaja
(NIAS), returned to the Netherlands 1921, working at the Hugo de Vries laboratory at
Amsterdam, professor of botany at the Transvaal University College, Pretoria, S. Africa
1924-1931, returned to the Netherlands as private scientist at the Botanical Museum and
Herbarium, Utrecht 1931-1976. (<em>Bremek</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: South African coll. at PRU (and PRE), Indonesian at BO, types of
his new taxa indicated in his publications, many at U.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 646; Barnhart 1: 246; BJI 2: 19; BL 1: 23, 59;
Bossert p. 52; Hortus 3: 1189; IF suppl. 3: 203, 4: 315; IH 2: 95; JW 2: 186, 4: 379; Kew 1:
350-352; MW p. 52; MW suppl. p. 28; Roon p. 21; SK 1: 78-79, 4: 98-99, cxlii; TL-1: 49;
TL-2/1: 315-316 and see indexes; Zander ed. 10, p. 640, ed. 11, p. 727.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Gunn, M. and L.E. Codd, Bot. expl. S. Afr. 103. 1981 (on S. Afr. period, portr.).
Koster, J. Th., Taxon 18: 550. 1969 (alg.).
Lanjouw, J., Acta bot. Neerl. 18: 6-7. 1969 (portr.).
Reed, C.R., Bibl. fl. S.E. Asia 18-19. 1969.
Stafleu, F.A., Jaarboek Kon. Ned. Akad. Wetensch., Amsterdam 1985: 170-172 (obit., portr.;
	b. 7 Feb 1888, d. 21 Dec 1984); Taxon 34: 390. 1985 (brief biogr.).
Steenis, C.G.G.J. van, Fl. Malesiana Bull. 38: 128. 1985 (brief note).
White, A.C. and B.L. Sloane, The Stapelieae ed. 2. 131. 1937 (portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Contributed 452 entries on <em>Acanthaceae</em> for ING, see ING 1: xviii.
1979.

summer 1951 between Bremekamp, J. Lanjouw and F.A. Stafleu.

*Brenckle, Jacob Frederic[k] (1875-1958), American physician and mycologist, studied at
Milwaukee Medical College, M.D. 1897, practicing physician at Kulm, North Dakota
1899-1923, served in the U.S. army in W.W. I, at Northville, S. Dakota 1923-1937, ultimately
at Millette, S. Dakota. (<em>Brenckle</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY. - Sets of his <em>Fungi dakotensis</em>: BM, BP, BPI, BRU, CUP, DAO,
HH(FH), IMI, L, M, MICH, MIN, MO, NDA, NY, PAD, PENN, PH, PUR, RMS, S, TRTC,
U, US. Guatemalan material MIN, US.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 246 (b. 14 Nov 1875); Ewan ed. 2: 26; IH 2: 95;
LS suppl. 3573-3578; NAF 7: 1053; Stevenson p. 1237; TL-2/1: 316.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Stevenson, J.A., Beih. Nova Hedwigia 36: 51-60. 1961.

Brendel, Frederik (1820-1912), German born (Erlangen), studied at the University of
Erlangen, M.D. 1843, assistant physician at the Bamberg city hospital 1846-1848, emigrated
to the United States 1850, journeying westward to Missouri, worked some time with
Engelmann, settled at Peoria, Illinois, active as physician. (<em>Brendel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: ILL. - Further material at B, US.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 247 (b. 20 Jan 1820, d. 10 Aug 1912); BJI 1: 7;
BL 1: 158, 175; BM 1: 231; IH 2: 95; Kew 1: 354; LS 3835; ME 3: 543; Morren ed. 10, p.
119; Tucker 1: 109 (10 entries).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Brendel, F., Amer. Natural. 13: 754-771. 1879 ("Historical sketch of science of
	botany in North America from 1635-1840").
Chase, V.H., Trans. Illinois State Acad. Sci. 24(2): 72-79. Dec 1931 (biogr., portr.).
Lack, H.W. and O. v. Sydow, Willdenowia 13: 415. 1983 (letters to Keck at UPS-UB).
Meadows, E.L., Trans. Illinois State Acad. Sci. 50: 66. 1957.

[Springfield 1859], Trans. Illinois State Agric. Soc. 3: 583-585. 1859, see TL-2/2: 757-758.

Brenner, Widar [Magnus] (1887-1932), Finnish botanist at Helsinki, son of H. Brenner,
Dr. phil., assistant with the Finnish geological committee 1919. (<em>Wid. Brenner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 247 (b. 16 Aug 1887, Helsinki, d. 12 Mar 1932,
ib.); BL 2: 68, 77, 83; KR p. 102.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1916: 173, 1927: 145; ÖBZ 81(3): 240. 1932 (d. 12 Mar 1932).

<em>markbeskaffenheten</em> ... Helsingfors (Statsrådets Tryckeri) 1921. Oct. (<em>Stud. veg. markbes-
kaff.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1921, p. [1]-105. <em>Copies</em>: KNAW, L. - Issued as Fennia 43(2), 1921. - German
	abstract: Studien über die Vegetation im westlichen Nyland (Süd-Finnland) und ihr
	Verhältnis zu den Eigenschaften des Bodens.

Brenner, Wilhelm (fl. 1900-1910), Swiss (Basel born) botanist and highschool teacher at
Basel, studied at the University of Basel, worked on his thesis at the Botanisches Institut der
Universität Halle-Wittenberg 1898-1899. (<em>W. Brenner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 247; Kew 1: 355.

von Val. Höfling, ..) 1900. Oct. (<em>Unters. Fettpfl.</em>).

HEADING: BRESÀDOLA

bot. Zeitung" ... 1902]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 4 Dec 1901 (in journal), cover (identif.), p. [i, id., recto of p. 114], [114]-160. <em>Copy</em>:
	B. - Reprinted and to be cited from Flora 90(1): 114-160. 1901 ("1902").

22.828. <em>Beiträge zur Blütenbiologie</em>. Wissenschaftliche Beilage zum Jahresbericht der Real-
schule zu Basel 1909-1910 ... Basel (Buchdruckerei Werner-Riehm) 1910. Qu. (<em>Beitr.
Bl.-Biol.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1910, cover-t.p., p. [1]-41, [42]. <em>Copies</em>: B, L.

*Bresàdola, Giacomo (1847-1929), Italian mycologist and clergyman, born in Ortisei,
Trento, primary schooling at Montichiari, subsequently at the Technical school at Rovereto
1859, entered the seminary in Trento 1863, ordination 1870, curate in various locations from
1864, ultimately 1887-1910 adminstrator of the cathedral chapter in Trento, lifelong dedica-
ting himself also to mycology. (<em>Bres</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Main herbarium was acquired by Lars Romell (1854-1927, see
TL-2/4: 876-877), who deposited it in S (see Phycologia 20: 50. 1928, info D.P. Rogers). -
Further material in B, CUP, FH, K (second set of herbarium), M, NY, PAD, PC, POR, TOR,
TR. - Contributed to C. Roumeguère, <em>Fungi exsiccati praecipue Gallici</em> (see TL-2/4: 934).
- <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Fungi tridentini</em> fasc. 1 (1881) - fasc. 14 (1900).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 226, 320, 327; Barnhart 1: 247 (b. 14 Feb 1847,
d. 9 Jun 1929), BJI 1: 7; BM 1: 231, 6: 125; Bossert p. 52; CSP 12: 118, 13: 793-794; DTS
1: 34, 3: xl, 6(4): 55; GR p. 431; GR, cat. p. 61; IH 2: 95, 549; Kew 1: 355; KR p. 102; LS
3839-3887, 31.514-31.518; LS suppl. 3623-3642; MW p. 53; NAF 9(6): 430, 7(15): 1053;
NI 229-231; Saccardo 1: 37, 2: 119; Stevenson p. 1237; TL-2/1: 317-319 and see indexes;
Urban-Berl. p. 274; WU 1: 112.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Ainsworth, G.C. and G.R. Bisby, Dict. fungi ed. 6. 78. 1971.
Anon., J. Mycol. 12: opp. 1, 137. 1906 (portr.); Bull. Lloyd Libr., Mycol. ser. 6: 95. 1912; J.
	Bot. 63: 168. 1936 (publ. of <em>Icon. mycol.</em>, TL-2/745 to be published at his 80-th year).
Bertram, G., Bull. Soc. mycol. France 100(1): xxii-xxiii. 1984 (brief sketch of life, portr.).
Bresàdola, G., Icon. mycol. 26: v-xvi. 1923 (bibl.).
Burgwitz, G.K., Mater. Mykol. Phytopath. 6: 1-2. 1927 (Russian).
Cappalletti, C., Lavori di Bot., Ist. Bot. Padova 20(6): 1-6. 1958 (repr. from Natura alpina
	5(4). 1954) (portr.).
Catoni, G., L'abate G. Bresàdola per l'80o compleano. Trento. 1927 (fide NI).
Fenaroli, L., L'Abate Giacomo Bresàdola e la sua opera micologia, Milano 1927, 12 p. (repr.
	from Riv. mens. Touring Club Ital. Jul 1927); Glorie d'Italia, L'abate Giacomo Bresàdola,
	La Vie d'Italia, Milano, Jul 1927, 11 p. (copy MO).
Heim, R., Ann. crypt. exot. 5(1): 5-15. 1932 ("l'oeuvre de G.B.").
Iseli, J., Schweiz. Z. Pilzk. 1939: 197-199 (obit., portr.).
Killermann, S., Z. Pilzk. ser. 2. 5: 121-128. 1926 (portr., bibl.), ser. 2. 8: 98-99. 1929.
Lloyd, C.G., Mycol. Not. 19: 218. 1905, 35: 462-463. 1910, <em>in</em> Syn. Stiput. Polypor. 1912
	(frontisp.), 70 (vol. 7(3)): 1220-1221. Sep 1932.
Murrill, W.A., Torreya 6: 233-234. 1906, Mycologia 22: 49-50. 1930 (portr.).

Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 65. 1905 (portr.).

HEADING: BRESÀDOLA

<sm>NOTES</sm>: (1) Bresàdola used three variations of his first name: Giacopo (Italian), Jacapo and
Iacapo (other languages).
(2) In 1979 was published: <em>Omnia Bresadolina extracta in unum collecta</em> ... by Gruppo
micologico G. Bresàdola, Trento (in occasione del 50° della morte di G. Bresàdola), [i-iv],
1-1055, being a copy of all publications of this author with portrait and col. photos of all
illustrations.

(2) With P.A. Saccardo, <em>Enumerazione dei fungi della Valsesia</em>, see TL-2/9924.

HEADING: BRETSCHNEIDER

*Bretschneider, Emil [Vasilievic] (1833-1901), Latvian sinologist and botanist, born in
Riga, studied medicine, physician to the Russian Embassy at Teheran 1862-1865, id. at Peking
1865-1884. (<em>Bretschn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE, further material at B, BM(228), FI, HH, K, MO, PH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 82; Barnhart 1: 248 (d. 29 Apr/12 Mai 1901 St.
Petersburg); BJI 1: 7; BM 1: 233, 6: 126; Bret. p. 1048-1061; CSP 13: 795; IH 2: 95; Jackson
p. 380; Kew 1: 356; Lipschitz 1: 272; Morren ed. 10, p. 151; MW p. 53; MW suppl. p. 28;
Plesch p. 156; Rehder 1: 459, 5(index): 119; SK 1: cxviii; TL-2/1: 320 and see indexes;
Urban-Berl. p. 333.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., J. Bot. 9: 320. 1871, 39: 287-288. 1901 (d. 14 Mai 1901); Bull. Soc. bot.
	France 19(Bibl.): 34-35. 1872 (rev. study value Chin. bot. works); Acta Horti Univ. Jurj.
	2: 131-132. 1901; Kew Bull. 1901: 201-202 (brief sketch of life); ÖBZ 51: 319. 1901 (d.);
	Bot. Not. 1902: 94.

	192 p.); J. Bot. 32: 292-294. 1894 ("on some old collections of Chinese plants" with a
	critical note by J. Britten).

Cordier, H., T'oung-Pao ser. 2. 2: 192-197. 1901 (portr., bibl., n.v. fide MW p. 84).
Cox, E.H.M., Plant hunting in China, Oxford 1986, xii, 230 p. (see p. 12, 15, 47, 93, 130).

Bretzl, Hugo (1878-x), German botanist and philologist, born at Diedolshausen, Kreis
Rappoltsweiler, educated at the Lyceum of Strassburg 1890-1897, studied classical philology
and botany with Ed. Schwartz and Solms-Laubach, collected in Algeria and Southern France
Mar-Apr 1900, Dr. phil. Strassburg 1902. (<em>H. Bretzl</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B(3500), further material HH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 248 (b. 25 Dec 1878, Diedolshausen); BL 2: 19;
Kew 1: 356; Moebius p. 7.

HEADING: BRIARD

der Philosophischen Fakultät der Kaiser-Wilhelms-Universität zu Strassburg ... Strassburg

*Brewer, James Alexander (1818-1886), British botanist, living in Reigate, Surrey, col-
lected some time in Australia, ultimately at Tonbridge, Kent. (<em>Brewer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: British material at RTE, further material at MANCH, NMW, OXF,
WAR (and see Kent and Allen 1984). - Western Australian material at BM(354), K,
MANCH. - Manuscripts at BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 248; BB p. 44, 339; BL 2: 268, 634; BM 1: 233;
Clokie p. 138; CSP 7: 255; Desmond p. 87 (b. 25 Feb 1818, Reigate, Surrey, d. Jan 1886,
Tonbridge, Kent); IH 2: 96; Jackson p. 258, 260, 526; Kew 1: 357; PR 1134-1135; Rehder
1: 400, 401; TL-2/1: 321 and see indexes; Tucker 1: 110.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. France 3: 256. 1856 (rev. <em>New fl. Reigate</em>).
Baker, J., J. Bot. 1: 310-315. Oct 1863 (detailed rev. of <em>Fl. Surrey</em>).

	Australia to collect ... for Wilson Saunders ...").

	material).
Schlechtendal, D.F.L. von, Bot. Zeit. 15(31): 536. 31 Jul 1857 (brief rev.).

Brez, Jacques (1771-1798), Dutch clergyman and botanist, born at Middelburg, sometime
at Utrecht, died at Middelburg. (<em>Brez</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<em>Publ</em>.: 1791, p. [i]-xxvi, [1]-324. <em>Copies</em>: BM, L, MO.

*Briard, Pierre-Alfred (1811-1896), French soldier, turned to botany in his retirement
dedicating himself to the study of the flora and cryptogames of the dépt. Aube. (<em>Briard</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 249; BL 2: 122-123; BM 1: 234; De Toni 4: ix;
Kew 1: 358; Rehder 1: 416; Stevenson p. 1237; TL-2/1: 323; Tucker 1: 110.

	bot. France 11 Mar 1892; supplément not seen by us).

PAGE: 72
HEADING: BRICK

Hariot, P., Bull. Soc. bot. France 35(Bibl.): 176-177. 1888 (rev. of <em>Fl. crypt. Aube</em>).

	de la ville de Troyes</em>, 122 p. 1895).
Mottey, Géneral Yves, Bull. Soc. mycol. France 100(1): vii. 1984 (brief life-sketch).

Brick, Carl (1863-1924), German (born Stolp in Preussen) botanist (phytopathologist),
educated at the Gymnasium of Stolp, the "Realschule I. Ordnung" and the "Realgymnasium
zu St. Johann" in Danzig, final examination 1882, studied natural sciences at the University
of Breslau 1882-1886, on military duty in Berlin 1886-1887, studied e.g. with F. and H. Cohn,
Engler and Göppert, Dr. phil. Breslau 1888, assistant at the Botanical Museum in Hamburg
1887-1888, first assistant at the Botanical Institute in Karlsruhe 1888, later again in Hamburg,
ultimately as scientific member of the Institute for applied botany, died on a field trip with
the "Gartenbauverein". (<em>Brick</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HBG. - Continued exsiccata by Otto Jaap, <em>Fungi selecti exsiccati</em> ser.
35-39, nos. 851-958 (see Otto Jaap).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 249 (b. 10 Feb 1863, Stolp, Pommern, Preussen);
BJI 2: 19; Christiansen p. 73, 75, 91, 181, 183, 254, 255, 262; IH 2: 96; LS 3921-3928,
31.531-31.542; LS suppl. 3673-3683; Rehder 5(index): 120; Stevenson p. 1237; Tucker 1:
110-111.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 65(3) (Beibl.): (195). 1925 (d. 18 Aug 1924).
Christiansen, W. and W., Bot. Schrifttum Schlesw.-Holst. 312 [index]. 1936.
Schmid, B. and C. Thesing, Biologen-Kalender 1: 175. 1914 (b. 10 Feb 1863, Stolp; list of
	publ.).
Stieber, M.T. et al., Huntia 4(1): 64. 1981 (letters to F.V. Coville at HU).
Weidner, H., Abh. Verh. naturw. Ver. Hamburg suppl. 9: 304-306. 1967.

22.854. <em>Beiträge zur Biologie</em> und vergleichenden Anatomie <em>der baltischen Strandpflanzen</em>.
Inaugural-Dissertation welche nebst beigefügten Thesen mit Genehmigung der hohen philo-
sophischen Fakultät der Universität Breslau behufs Erlangung der Doctorwürde Mittwoch,
den 29 Februar 1888, Vormittags 11 Uhr, ... Danzig (Druck von A.W. Kafemann) 1888. Oct. (<em>Beitr. Biol. balt. Strandpfl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 29 Feb 1888 (date of defense thesis), p. [1]-53, <em>pl. 2.</em> <em>Copies</em>: B, G, NSUB/GOET. -
	Preprinted from Schr. naturf. Ges. Danzig 7(1): 108-156. 1888.
<em>Note</em>: Thesis no. 2 on p. 53: "Die Characeen bilden das unterste Glied der Bryophyten".

E.H. Senats Buchdruckern) 1893. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1893, cover-t.p., p. [1]-14. <em>Copy</em>: L. - Reprinted and to be cited from Jahrb. Hamb. Wiss.
	Anst. 10(2): 111-124. 1893. - "(Arbeiten des Botanischen Museums [Hamburg] 1892)".

des Naturwissenschaftlichen Vereins in Hamburg ... 1897 [i.e. 1898]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1897-1898 (in journal, Verhandlungen für 1897, Nat. Nov. Jul (1) 1899 sic), p. [1]-40.

PAGE: 73
HEADING: BRIEGER

*Bridel(-Brideri), Samuel-Elisée de (1761-1828), Swiss bryologist, born Crassier, Vaud,
Switzerland, studied at the University of Lausanne, called to Gotha as teacher of the princes
August and Friedrich von Sachsen-Gotha, subsequently private secretary and librarian to the
prince-hereditary, visited Paris and Rome, ultimately "Geheimer Legationsrath", received
letters of nobility ("de Bridel"), after his marriage added his wife's name Brideri. (<em>Brid</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (1200; see TL-2/1: 324); phanerogamic herbarium at H (7000, rd.
1829), an other Bridel herbarium was given to LAU in 1854 (Wilczeck 1937); further material
at GOET (Fungi, alg.), FI, L, LZ.

<sm>NOTES</sm>: (1) For a detailed treatment see MD p. 60-67.
(2) Published in Paris a collection of poems: "Délassements poétiques".

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 3: 328 (A. Engler); AG 12(2): 335; Barnhart 1: 250 (b.
28 Nov 1761, Crassier nr. Nyon, d. 7 Jan 1828, Gotha); BM 1: 235; CSP 1: 624; DTS 1:
34-35; Frank 3(Anh.): 14; Hegi 6(2): 1272; IH 2: 96; Jackson p. 153; Kew 1: 358; Lasègue
p. 320, 334, 545; MD p. 60-67, 239 (extensive treatment); Moebius p. 117, 121; NAF ser. 2.
9: 121; PR 1143-1145, ed. 1: 1270-1272; SBC p. 116; TL-1: 50-51; TL-2/1: 324-325 and see
indexes; Urban-Berl. p. 295.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Flora 11(1): 335-336. 1828, 12(Beil. 1): 15-16. 1829 (list of herbaria and
	books to be sold in Gotha 5 Feb 1829); Nouv. biogr. anc. mod. nouv. ed. 3: 144. 1843-1847;
	Nouv. biogr. univ. 7: 382-383. 1863.
Balmer, H., Gesnerus 37: 133-138. 1980.
Barnhart, J.H., Mem. Torrey bot. Club 16: 291. 1921.
Bridel-Brideri, S.E., Notice sur la naissance et les progrès des sciences dans le Canton de
	Vaud, Feuille Canton Vaud 9(109): 1-22 (n.v., fide Johnson, Huntia 6(1): 21. 1985).
Briquet, J., Ber. Schweiz. bot. Ges. 50a: 69-71. 1940 (important account of life, sources,
	dedications, publications).
Candolle, A.P. de, Mém. souv. 142, 411. 1862.
Collander, R., Hist. bot. Finland 102. 1965.
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 90. 1969.
Forbes, R.J., ed., Martinus van Marum 2: 302, 362-363, 374. 1970.

Hiepko, P., Willdenowia 8(2): 392. 1978 (herb. B. at B (special collection)).

Röll, J., Mitt. Thür. bot. Ver. 32: 1-4. 1915.
Rogers, A.D., William Starling Sullivant 135, 149, 164, 178, 234. 1940.
Rose, H.J., A new gen. biogr. dict. 5: 53. 1857.
Rothmaler, W., Mitt. Thür. bot. Ver. 41: 46-47. 1933.

	60. 1959.

Wilczeck, E., Bull. Soc. Vaud. Sci. nat. 60: 12. 1937 ("Doyen Bridel" gave a B. herbarium
	to LAU).

Brieger, Friedrich Gustav (1900-x), German geneticist, born at Breslau, studied at the
Bussey Institution at Harvard University, later at the Kaiser-Wilhelm-Institut für Biologie in
Berlin-Dahlem. (<em>Brieger</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 250 (b. 11 Oct 1900, Breslau); Kew 1: 358-359.

Brierley, William Broadhurst (1889-1963), British agricultural botanist, school teacher
Manchester 1907-1909, studied at the University of Manchester, B. Sc. 1911, M. Sc. 1912,
D. Sc. 1920, lecturer economic botany 1911-1914, assistant at Kew, pathologic laboratory
1914-1918, Rothamsted Experiment Station head department plant pathology 1918-1932,
professor of agricultural botany at the University of Reading 1932-1954. (<em>Brierley</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TRT.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 232, 327; Barnhart 1: 250 (b. 19 Feb 1889);
Desmond p. 88 (b. 19 Feb 1889, Manchester, d. Keswick, Cumberland, 20 Feb 1963); IH 2:
96; Kew 1: 359; LS suppl. 3686-3702.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Gard. Chron. ser. 3. 77: 104. 1925 (portr.); Who was who 1961-1970: 134.
	1972; The Times 1 Mar 1963.
Brierley, W.B., on Chronica Botanica post card, now in files TL-2 7 Jul 1939 (data).
Gager, C.S., Brooklyn Bot. Gard. Rec. 27(3): 252. 1938 (director Agric. bot. Garden, Reading
	Univ. from 1932).
Hunt Institution, Dict. bot. portr. coll. 52. 1972 (b. 19 Feb 1889, Manchester, d. Feb 1963,
	Keswick).

Briganti, Francesco (1802-1865), Italian botanist, born 18 Apr 1802, Naples, as son of
Vincenzo Briganti (see TL-2/1: 325-326), continued the works of his father as professor at
the University of Naples, died 21 Dec 1865, Naples. (<em>F. Brig.</em>).

*Briggs, Thomas Richard Archer (1838-1891), British botanist, born at Fursdon (nr.
Plymouth), from 1844/1845 his family moved to Plymouth where he lived for the rest of his
life, of independent means, dedicated himself to the botany of the area of Plymouth, ultimately
moving again to Fursdon. (<em>Briggs</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (incl. <em>Rubus</em>), further material in AK, BM (1602), GL, MANCH,
NMW, NOT, OXF, PLY (destroyed), WAR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(4): 33; Barnhart 1: 251; BB p. 45; BL 2: 235; BM 1:
235; Bossert p. 53; Clokie p. 138; CSP 1: 626, 7: 259-260, 9: 349; Desmond p. 88 (b. 7 Mai
1838, d. 23 Jan 1891); IH 2: 96; Jackson p. 258; Kew 1: 360; Morren ed. 10, p. 76; Rehder
5(index): 120; TL-2/1: 326 and see indexes.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Britten. J., J. Bot. 18: 281-285. Sep 1880.
Davey, F.H., Fl. Cornwall li. 1909 (portr.).
Kent, D.H., Brit. herbaria 45. 1957.
Kent. D.H. and D.E. Allen, Brit. Irish herbaria 101. 1984.
Martin, W.K. and G.T. Fraser, Fl. Devon 774. 1939.
Moyle Rogers, W., J. Bot. 29: 97-106. 1891 (main biogr., portr.).
Stieber, M.T. et al., Huntia 4(1): 64. 1981 (2 letters of B. to J.G. Baker at HU).
Watson, H.C., Topographical botany ed. 2. 539. 1883.
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 76. 1905 (on portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Contributed to H.C. Watson, <em>London cat. Brit. pl.</em> ed. 6. 1887.

*Brignoli di Brunnhoff, Giovanni de (1774-1857), Italian botanist, born in Gradisca (Fri-
uli-Venecia Giulia), professor of botany and agriculture at the Convict-Collegium at Urbino
1808, id. at the University of Modena 1817-1855. (<em>Brign</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BASSA, further material in FI, MOD, PAD.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 432 (sub De Brignoli); BM 1: 236; Bossert p. 97;

159; Lasègue p. 340, 342; LS 3948; PR 1150-1153, ed. 1: 1279-1282; Rehder 5(index): 120;
Saccardo 1: 38, 178-179, 2: 24, cron. p. xvii; TL-2/1: 326; Tucker 1: 111.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Flora 39(1): 287. 1856 (retired 1855, succeeded by Hector (Ettori) Celi),

22.872. <em>Horti botanici</em> R. Archigymnasii <em>mutiensis historia</em> ... adjecta horti ejusdem ichno-

Brill, Otto (1885-x), German forester, born 23 Mai 1885 in Ebersgöns (Kreis Wetzlar) at the
four-year Volksschule at Ebersgöns 1895-1901, at the Grossherzogliche Realschule zu
Butbach (Hessen) 1901-1903, in 1903 at the University Marburg, 1905 Sommer-Semester at
Bonn, 1905-1906 again in Marburg,Dr. 1908. (<em>O. Brill</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Brinkman, Alfred Henry (1873-1945), English born bryologist, on Lighthouse service,
England 1895-1908, emigrated to Canada 1908, settled at Craigmyle, Alberta, surveyor and
topographer in Rocky Mountain forests. (<em>Brinkm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HH (6000 nos.?), further material at ALTA, B, BM, CAFB, CGE,
CV, DBN, E, K, MICH, MT, MTJB, NY, OXF, PAE, PH, QFA, UAC, US, V, W, WTU. -
Issued also <em>Canadian mosses</em> exsicc., set of nos. 1-154 at HH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 252 (b. 28 Feb 1873, Poplar, London, England);

p. 295.

Brinkmann, Wilhelm (1861-1917), German (Westphalia, Lengerich) botanist (mycologist),
educated at the teacher's seminar at Soest 1879-1882, teacher at Ladbergen 1882, idem at
Lengerich 1882-1916, specialized on the Westphalian Hymenomycetes. (<em>Brinkmann</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Issued <em>Westfälische Pilze in getrockneten Exemplaren</em>, 200 taxa of
Thelephoreae, Hydnaceae and Polyporaceae, 1900-1908, nos. 1-200, Lengerich (see also
"Autoreferat" by Brinkmann, Bot. Centralbl. 105(43): 434-435. 20 Oct 1907, nos. 1-150).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 252; LS 3951-3954, 31.555-31.556; LS suppl.
3718.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Alg. Bot. Z. 22: 137. 6 Mai 1917 (d. 6 Jan 1917, Osnabrück).
De Toni, G.B., Bull. Soc. bot. ital. 1919(7-9): 59-62 (obit.).
Koenen, O., Jahresber. Westfäl. Prov.-Ver. Wiss. Kunst, Bot. 44: 5-6. 1916 (obit., b. 5 Aug
	1861, Lengerich, d. 6 Jan 1917, Osnabrück).
